SUMMARY: ArsR negatively controls expression of genes involved in arsenical and antimonite metals resistance whose expression is induced in presence of se metals [7860609, 7721697, 8764681, 8576202]. This protein is autoregulated; arsR is first gene in arsRBC operon that it regulates [7721697]. ArsR belongs to ArsR/SmtB family of transcriptional regulators that respond to a variety of metals [12829264]. ArsR has a helix-turn-helix motif for DNA binding, a metal-binding site [8051064] and a dimerization domain [9188467]. inducer-binding sites for members of this family appear to have arisen by convergent evolution [17897948]. In ArsR inducer-binding site contains three cysteine residues that bind arsenite and antimonite specifically and with high affinity [8051064, 8621591]. Dimerization of ArsR is required for DNA binding and its ability to act as a transcriptional repressor [9188467]. dimer recognizes and binds to a 12-2-12 inverted repeat [12829264, 8576202] but binding of arsenic or antimonite to ArsR causes a conformational change in it, leading to dissociation from DNA and hence derepression [8621591]. chromosomal ArsR shows 75% identity to ArsR of Escherichia coli plasmid R773 and 26% identity to staphylococcal plasmid pI258 and pSX267 ArsR proteins [7860609]. ArsR when overexpressed has capacity to remove arsenic species from contaminated water [15294789, 23484908]. ArsR: homologous to arsenate inducibility regulator [7721697]. Review: [12829264].
